vectorData.altText: That's right! Principle or chief cells of the parathyroid gland are smaller and clustered together forming knots of cells. They secrete parathyroid hormone in response to decreased blood calcium levels.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
H10   Chief Cells Produce Parathyroid Hormone

At low magnification (a), a small lobule of the parathyroid gland is seen to be separated from others by CT septae (S). The parenchyma of the parathyroid glands is seen to be composed of composed of principle or chief cells (P) and oxyphil cells (O).
At higher magnification, the principle cells of the parathyroid gland are seen to be arranged in densely-packed knots that surround fenestrated capillaries (C). Principle cells respond directly to decreased blood Ca2+ levels with the production and secretion of parathyroid hormone, PTH, which elevates blood Ca2+ levels through actions on bone, the digestive tract and the kidneys. In bone tissue, PTH stimulates osteoblast production of osteoclast-stimulating factor, which promotes osteolysis and the release of Ca2+ from bone matrix. PTH promotes the activation of vitamin D, and therefore plays an indirect role in Ca2+ absorption from the gut. In the kidneys, PTH promotes the reabsorption of Ca2+, and therefore decreases the excretion of Ca2+ in urine.
Oxyphil cells often form clusters within the lobules of the parathyroid gland. They may demonstrate a low level of PTH synthesis. Their functional significance is uncertain.
Oxyphil Cells (O)  larger cells, eosinophilic cytoplasm
Principle Cells (O)  majority in parathyroid, smaller, secrete PTH
